reflections.self_assessment: I liked that I was willing to go on early teams and didn’t panic after the first fail, but I clearly didn’t adjust my reads fast enough after back-to-back failed missions that included me. I need to be more vocal about process-of-elimination logic and push harder on narrowing down the likely evils instead of staying relatively passive and trusting the wrong people.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-key, cooperative evil game; being on the first successful mission made him look safe and he didn’t draw much suspicion afterward.
player_observations.Charlie: Took on leadership confidently and seemed to frame arguments logically, which made him feel trustworthy even when his mission failed and should have drawn more scrutiny.
player_observations.Diana: Was assertive and comfortable being on multiple teams, and her calm reaction to mission fails helped her blend in and avoid being singled out as the source of sabotage.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed reasonably cautious and measured in their comments, avoiding big loud pushes, which in hindsight fit a Merlin style of subtly guiding without over-committing to hard accusations.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted my early reads and built consistently successful teams, which helped maintain a clean mission record, but I didn’t think enough about how those choices exposed Merlin. I should have been more cautious about repeatedly including Eve and maybe added a bit more doubt or variation to protect her identity. In future games, I’ll try to balance picking strong, trusted teams with making sure our information doesn’t make Merlin an easy target.

player_observations.Bob: Played in a very straightforward and cooperative way, which made him seem naturally good and relatively easy to trust. Didn’t push many strong accusations, which kept him low profile and unlikely to be suspected as evil or Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed patience and didn’t need to force suspicion aggressively, which helped him gather enough information to make an accurate assassination. His social presence felt measured rather than loud, which likely made his final Merlin guess more believable and less questioned.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well with the good team during the clean missions, benefiting from the lack of fails and limited hard conflicts. Seemed comfortable staying somewhat in the background, letting others drive team choices while still not drawing attention as evil.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to guide teams effectively—every mission succeeded—while still not being blatantly outspoken, which is impressive for Merlin. However, her consistent inclusion on successful teams and the subtle trust she generated appear to have made her identity readable enough for the assassin to nail the final guess.

reflections.self_assessment: I was reasonably consistent in keeping suspicion off the confirmed-evil pair early, but I didn’t translate my knowledge into a clear good-leaning path for the team, especially around Missions 2 and 4. I could improve by signaling my trust in Bob and Charlie more strongly and earlier, and by steering teams away from Diana and Eve without looking like I had perfect information.

player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and felt genuinely conflicted after Mission 2, which read as authentically good but also made it harder for him to hard-push back on bad team comps. He tends to rely on mission results more than strong gut reads, which made him somewhat swayable late.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as quietly logical and not overly forceful, which made him seem more trustworthy but also easier to sideline from key decisions. He didn’t strongly leverage his good alignment to demand better teams, especially after Mission 3’s fail.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as leader on Mission 1 with a clean success, which gave her lingering credibility. She played assertively but not aggressively, and managed to stay on multiple teams without drawing enough heat even after suspicious results.
player_observations.Eve: Used Mission 2 effectively to create ambiguity, keeping suspicion spread out rather than focused on herself. She was comfortable taking leadership on Missions 2 and 4 and proposing mixed teams that always had at least one evil, while framing them as reasonable compromises.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted the early clean missions (1 and 3) but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in Diana as confirmed good and to systematically eliminate Charlie and Eve from future teams. I should have argued more forcefully against including Charlie after the Mission 2 fail and against adding Eve to the otherwise clean pair in Mission 4. Next time, I’ll be more vocal in connecting mission results to concrete team constraints so evil has less room to maneuver on the final mission.

player_observations.Bob: Played like a cautious information-holder, often avoiding direct accusations, which fits Merlin but sometimes made it hard for the table to confidently follow his reads. His willingness to go on the final team with Charlie despite the prior failed mission with him suggests he prioritized subtlety over clearly steering good away from known risks.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, he inserted himself into early teams and took a single, controlled fail that created lasting doubt without overexposing himself. He leaned on social persuasion to keep himself team-eligible late in the game, which paid off on the final mission.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as consistently logical and was part of two clean missions, which fit her genuine good role. However, she still accepted a risky configuration on the last mission, suggesting she sometimes deferred too much to others’ confidence instead of strictly trusting mission data.
player_observations.Eve: Blended into the background of the discussion well enough that her inclusion on Mission 4 felt plausible rather than clearly dangerous. Her single, timely sabotage on that mission created confusion without making her look like the obvious evil choice afterward.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy, which helped get clean teams approved and contributed to three straight successful missions without drawing much suspicion. I could improve by being a bit more vocal in questioning others so evil feels more pressure, while still avoiding looking like I had extra information.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-key Merlin, guiding team selections subtly enough that the assassin misfired on Diana instead of him.
player_observations.Charlie: As evil, approved all successful missions, suggesting a more passive or long-game approach that avoided obvious sabotage but also failed to create doubt about the good teams.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as very reliably good, accepting and leading teams that all succeeded, which made her a natural (but ultimately incorrect) target for the assassin.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin read social cues well enough to identify an influential good player, but overestimated Diana’s informational role, suggesting a need to differentiate between ‘trusted good’ and ‘hidden Merlin’ more carefully.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed believable as non-Merlin-aligned evil by not pushing hard for any fails and blending into the early mission successes, which preserved team trust but ultimately gave Merlin a very safe game. I should have worked more actively with Charlie to create confusion around Merlin’s identity and pushed for at least one controlled fail to generate mistrust, instead of allowing a clean sweep that made the assassination mostly a shot in the dark.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very subtle Merlin game, giving just enough quiet support to correct teams without drawing suspicion, especially by consistently backing teams that included me without overexplaining why.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, seemed hesitant to introduce chaos or push controversial team comps, which kept table tension low but deprived us of the noisy information we needed for a better assassination guess.
player_observations.Diana: Played a straightforward, transparently good style, trusting early and not over-theorizing, which helped her look clean and made it harder for us to frame her as a potential Merlin.
player_observations.Eve: Appeared relatively low-impact in table-shaping, neither strongly driving team decisions nor loudly solving, which made her an appealing but ultimately incorrect assassination target.

reflections.self_assessment: I managed information fairly well this game, especially by not over-clearing Diana and Eve too early while still pushing missions toward mostly good teams. I could improve by seeding more plausible suspicion on myself as a regular good player, since my consistent presence on successful teams and resistance to some evil-leaning proposals probably contributed to Eve being a plausible Merlin candidate rather than fully muddying the waters.

player_observations.Bob: Aggressive and opportunistic, willing to take the risky early fail on Mission 3 and then lean on social persuasion rather than mechanical safety. He seemed comfortable driving the narrative, which makes him dangerous in later games as either alignment.
player_observations.Charlie: More low-key and reactive, blending into discussions instead of strongly leading them, which let him avoid heavy scrutiny even after Mission 4 failed under his leadership. This quieter approach works well for evil but may cause trust issues when he’s actually good.
player_observations.Diana: Played very straightforwardly, voting and speaking in ways that matched a typical cautious good player, which made it easier to trust her after the pattern of mission results emerged. She didn’t push hard theories but supported reasonable teams reliably.
player_observations.Eve: Appeared consistently logical and was often in the center of team discussions as an anchor of apparent reasonableness, which made her a natural Merlin suspect in the assassination phase. Her willingness to take leadership and accept responsibility for critical missions added to her perceived informational authority.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fail on Mission 3 well and stayed mostly under the radar, helping set up a believable narrative that kept suspicion spread out. I could improve by pushing a bit harder on alternative Merlin candidates earlier, as I only narrowed in on Bob late and might have missed him if good had coordinated their table talk better.

player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and consistently chose solid, low-risk teams, which fit Merlin’s information advantage; his reluctance to push hard accusations while subtly steering away from Eve was a big tell in retrospect.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and somewhat reactive, following table consensus more than driving it, which made him seem generically good but not especially informed.
player_observations.Diana: Took initiative as leader and was willing to include a mix of players, which made her look open and cooperative; her willingness to be on multiple early teams without much resistance made her feel like a safe, non-Merlin good.
player_observations.Eve: Blended in well as evil by supporting reasonable team choices early and only letting a fail through when it was plausibly deniable, maintaining a good-aligned image for most of the game.

reflections.self_assessment: I consistently put myself on teams and maintained a generally trustworthy image, which helped get multiple missions approved with me on them. However, I relied too much on repeated team structures without systematically testing suspects, so I didn’t narrow down the evil players fast enough and let them blend into successful missions.

player_observations.Bob: Played very cautiously and avoided drawing too much suspicion, managing to be on both successful and failed missions without standing out as the likely source of the fail.
player_observations.Charlie: Felt relatively low-key and analytical, not pushing too hard but subtly steering choices in ways that in hindsight were often correct for good.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed earnest and straightforward, and her mission leadership didn’t strongly clear or condemn anyone, which made it hard to use her teams as solid alignment indicators.
player_observations.Eve: Played an assertive and central role in team formation, projecting confidence and using early mission successes to build trust that later allowed her to slip fails through.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently towny and built a strong trust link with Charlie through clean mission results, which helped keep suspicion off Merlin and secure all three missions. I could improve by contributing more explicit, logical reasoning during team discussions so that my reads are clearer and less reliant on the mission outcomes alone.

player_observations.Bob: You played subtly as evil, not overpushing bad teams, but the clean early missions made you look increasingly isolated and slightly out of the main trust network.
player_observations.Charlie: You played very collaboratively and logically, reinforcing trust through repeated successful missions and making yourself a natural hub for good-leaning coordination.
player_observations.Diana: You did a solid job as Merlin, nudging things in the right direction without drawing too much heat, especially by supporting safe team constructions without overselling your reads.
player_observations.Eve: You stayed quiet enough to avoid early hard suspicion, but your assassin shot on me suggests you may have overweighted mission participation and underweighted subtle behavioral cues from Diana.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar, leading a clean first mission and then subtly supporting later fails without drawing too much suspicion, which helped evil secure the win. I could improve by more actively shaping team compositions and table talk to frame specific good players (especially Eve) as suspicious or as potential Merlin, rather than just blending in.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to accept being placed on teams and played in a straightforward, trusting way, which made her seem reliably good but not especially vocal in pushing accusations.
player_observations.Charlie: Was willing to go on risky teams and seemed to trust patterns too quickly, which made him manipulable in team selection and helped evil sneak onto critical missions.
player_observations.Diana: Played aggressively and was willing to fail missions at key moments, leaning into the assassin role with bold moves that created chaos and doubt among the good players.
player_observations.Eve: Tried to guide team selection subtly rather than forcefully, which kept her alive and less obvious as Merlin but also meant her influence wasn’t strong enough to prevent repeated bad team choices.

reflections.self_assessment: I played fairly trusting this game, which helped missions pass smoothly but meant I didn’t push hard enough to distinguish between quiet good players and well-hidden evil. I also didn’t think deeply about Merlin’s identity before the assassination, so I missed chances to protect Eve by adding more doubt around other players.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently looked solid and reliable, and her willingness to go on early teams helped build quick trust without drawing suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Flew under the radar this game, avoiding strong pushes or controversial decisions, which made it hard to get any real read on them.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed low-key and didn’t need to fight team proposals hard, which kept her from being scrutinized even though all missions passed.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as very trustworthy and steady in team discussions, giving just enough guidance to look good without seeming overly controlling—though apparently it was still readable enough for the assassin.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted Eve too easily after Mission 2, rationalizing the single fail in a way that let evil stay hidden for too long, and I didn’t push hard enough to scrutinize team compositions that repeatedly included the same suspicious players. I did reasonably well at staying calm and not overreacting to early fails, but I need to be more vocal about patterns across missions and more willing to challenge 'convenient' narratives that let certain players skate by.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played a very quiet, subtle Merlin game—she nudged teams in the right direction early (like Mission 1) without overtly hard-clearing or hard-accusing anyone, which made it tough to confidently read her as Merlin while still giving evil some resistance.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played a straightforward, transparent style and seemed genuinely confused by the midgame logic knots, which made him read consistently good but also meant he didn’t exert strong influence over the critical team decisions.
player_observations.Diana: Diana balanced trust-building and targeted sabotage well; she got onto key teams without drawing much suspicion and her accusations felt calm and measured, which helped her pass as good long enough for evil to secure crucial mission fails.
player_observations.Eve: Eve leaned into being active and involved in team discussions, using that visibility to appear helpful while subtly steering lineups toward at least one evil player; her early willingness to sit with partial suspicion but not overdefend herself made her harder to pin down.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified Charlie and Eve as evil early, but I struggled to steer team selections and voting without revealing myself as Merlin too obviously. I should have been more decisive in arguing against Charlie and Eve on Missions 2, 4, and 5 while framing my logic in more 'generic suspicion' terms so I didn’t look like I had extra information.

player_observations.Alice: Very consistently trusted and often chosen for missions, Alice projected a solidly good image and didn’t over-argue, which made her a safe default pick. She tends to follow logical arguments presented by others rather than drive the table talk herself.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played a strong, low-key evil game by embedding himself in early teams and only failing when it maximized doubt, especially on Mission 2. He argued just enough to redirect suspicion without becoming the loudest or most obviously manipulative voice.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played like a cautious but rational good player, being willing to go on missions and accept logical team constructions. She didn’t push hard theories but instead reacted to emerging information, which made her look reliably good but also somewhat steerable.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s evil play hinged on getting onto the critical later mission and using that single fail on Mission 4 to sow confusion without overexposure. She maintained a fairly neutral table presence, avoiding heavy accusations and thereby staying under the radar until it was too late.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed subtle enough as Merlin that the assassin mis-guessed, while still nudging teams toward all-success missions, which is the core objective. I could improve by spreading my influence a bit more evenly so it’s less obvious when I’m strongly confident about specific players, and by creating a bit more plausible doubt around Diana to protect her from being read as 'cleared by Merlin.'

player_observations.Alice: Played very solidly pro-good, proposing and accepting clean teams in a way that felt natural and consistent; her lack of hesitation on good teams helped build quiet trust around her. Could occasionally telegraph confidence a bit strongly, which might make her look Merlin-adjacent in other games.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well early by not overpushing against any of the successful teams, which made their evil alignment less obvious in such a short game. However, the lack of constructive alternatives or clear reasoning on team suggestions was a small red flag that might stand out in longer games.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as very trustworthy with calm, straightforward logic and no defensive overreactions, which made her an ideal anchor for mission teams. Her leadership on Mission 2 was particularly clean, but the strength of that read also risked making her look like a likely Merlin candidate, which the assassin eventually targeted.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, made a reasonable guess in targeting Diana, reflecting how strongly good she appeared and how central she was to successful missions. Could improve by paying closer attention to who is subtly steering team selection and discussion tempo rather than just who looks the most trustworthy.
player_observations.Bob: N/A

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed subtle enough as Merlin to avoid drawing a correct assassination, while still guiding teams toward all-success missions, which is exactly what good needed. I could improve by adding a bit more apparent skepticism or occasional misreads so my correct calls don’t look too clean in retrospect.

player_observations.Alice: Played evil very quietly and blended into the early successful missions, which helped avoid suspicion but may have been too passive to meaningfully redirect team choices.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, pushed just enough doubt to keep options open, but their final Merlin guess suggests they relied more on surface-level table talk than on carefully tracking who subtly steered mission choices.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently looked very trustworthy, and her willingness to be on and lead key successful missions reinforced a strong good image that made her a natural shield for Merlin.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as genuinely good but didn’t exert heavy influence on team selection, which kept her off the assassin’s radar but also limited her impact on shaping the mission lineups.

reflections.self_assessment: I managed to get a crucial fail on Mission 3 without drawing too much immediate heat, and I helped push through a bad team on Mission 4, keeping evil in contention. However, I misread Merlin’s signal density and over-weighted Eve’s late-game confidence, causing a wrong assassination; I need to track early subtle guidance from Merlin more carefully and cross-check it against voting patterns instead of focusing so much on endgame table talk.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, giving just enough guidance to get good teams approved (especially on Missions 2 and 5) without obviously hard-clearing anyone; her calm consistency and non-flashy steering made her look like generic ‘solid good’ rather than a power role.
player_observations.Charlie: Did solid, low-profile evil work by participating in the Mission 4 fail without making it feel like a huge information event, blending his voting and table talk well enough that suspicion stayed diffuse rather than focused on him.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally good by accepting some risk on teams and not forcing herself into every mission, which made her successful participation on Missions 1, 2, and 5 look like organic trust rather than coordinated signaling.
player_observations.Eve: Showed confident leadership and table presence, especially as a frequent team member and final leader, which made her look like a likely information hub and drew my Merlin read; her assertiveness without being over-defensive was convincing enough to mislead my assassination.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Diana early and stayed consistently suspicious of Alice and Eve based on mission outcomes, which helped me read the table reasonably well. However, I failed to communicate my reads in a way that clearly protected me from being identified as Merlin and also didn’t push hard enough to keep Eve off the final mission, which ultimately let evil win. Next time I should shape my voting and table talk to be more subtly persuasive while also looking more plausibly confused.

player_observations.Alice: You played assertively and were willing to take high-impact leadership spots (Mission 3) to steer outcomes, and you balanced your visible suspicion level well enough to secure the assassination. Your ability to stay on teams without drawing overwhelming backlash shows you manage social perception effectively.
player_observations.Charlie: You played cautiously and didn’t force your views too hard, which made you look consistently good but also meant your information didn’t drive team selection as much as it could have. Your quieter style is trustworthy, but you could sometimes benefit from pushing your reads more clearly, especially near the final mission.
player_observations.Diana: You projected a very trustworthy, proactive good presence, especially with your early mission leadership and team choices that generally helped good. Even after being on failing teams later, you maintained credibility, which suggests your table talk and demeanor are naturally convincing.
player_observations.Eve: You blended in well as a flexible team member, getting onto multiple critical missions while avoiding becoming the primary suspect until quite late. Your ability to sit on both a clean second mission and later failing missions without being locked out shows you’re good at managing suspicion and adapting your story as the game evolves.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently credible as a likely good player, especially by choosing a clean team on Mission 3 and sharing suspicion with Eve in a way that didn’t expose us together. I could improve by more actively shaping the table’s read on Charlie earlier, as he flew under the radar enough that I never fully locked in a Merlin read during play.

player_observations.Alice: Played very proactively and often put herself on teams, which made her look confident and ‘central’ to the game state but also kept her under constant scrutiny. Tended to argue from logic and mission structure rather than gut reads, which made her look more village-aligned even when she was occasionally wrong.
player_observations.Charlie: Kept a relatively low profile but contributed just enough analysis to seem helpful without over-directing the table, a classic subtle Merlin pattern. His suspicions were generally accurate but delivered gently, often as questions or soft nudges rather than hard pushes.
player_observations.Diana: Played cautiously and seemed to rely heavily on mission outcomes and consensus rather than pushing strong original theories. Her team proposals and reactions felt sincere but somewhat reactive, making her read as clearly good but not especially influential.
player_observations.Eve: Balanced risk and subtlety well: she took and passed Mission 1 to build trust, then later positioned herself flexibly on critical teams without drawing obvious ‘evil coordinator’ heat. Her willingness to go on multiple key missions while varying overt confidence helped her look like a bold good player instead of a scheming evil one.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistent and non-threatening as an early leader, which helped Mission 1 pass cleanly and kept suspicion off me for most of the game. However, I failed to create enough doubt around Diana and didn’t coordinate well enough with Eve to steer the assassination away from a blind guess on Alice.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and leaned into early, clean success, which made her look reliably good without over-asserting herself. Her presence on all successful missions helped her appear trustworthy enough to draw the assassin’s shot.
player_observations.Charlie: Accepted and proposed safe, low-conflict teams that passed, projecting a calm, logical good-player image. He didn’t push hard accusations, which made it difficult to frame him as suspicious later.
player_observations.Diana: Played a subtle Merlin game—quiet but influential through team approvals, nudging toward consistently good teams without loudly directing traffic. Her low-key style kept her off the radar enough that she wasn’t the prime assassination target.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed conservative and avoided risky fails, which preserved team trust but left her with limited information and leverage in the endgame. The assassination on Alice suggests she followed surface-level trust patterns rather than deeply questioning who was quietly steering outcomes.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well at staying engaged in team discussions and trying to build consistent reasoning from one mission to the next. However, I tunneled too hard on trusting Diana after Mission 1 and didn't adjust quickly enough when patterns started pointing to her as the common denominator on failing teams. In the future, I should be more willing to reevaluate my assumptions after each mission result, especially when the same player appears repeatedly on failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played as a steady, straightforward good player, consistently willing to go on missions and seemed genuinely frustrated by the fails, which in hindsight fit her being good. She didn’t over-push accusations, which made her easier for evil to frame as suspicious when multiple failed missions included her.
player_observations.Bob: Kept a relatively low profile and avoided being on too many early teams, which helped him dodge suspicion for a long time. His inclusion on the failing Mission 3 team felt like a one-off at the time, but in hindsight that quiet, conservative approach worked very well for an evil player.
player_observations.Diana: Very effective as assassin, projecting reliability early by being on the successful first mission and then leveraging that trust to get repeatedly onto later teams. Her confident team proposals and willingness to go on risky missions made her look like a proactive good player, which I bought into for too long.
player_observations.Eve: Played quite subtly for Merlin, not over-directing the table or making aggressive calls, which helped avoid drawing a clear target on themselves. Their late-game positioning on my Mission 4 team suggests they were trying to nudge good toward a better combination without revealing too much, but my misreads on Diana undercut that help.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed quiet and uncontroversial, which helped evil avoid suspicion while the good team kept picking clean teams. I correctly identified Eve as Merlin based on how consistently she was trusted onto teams and how comfortable she seemed with the team compositions; in the future, I could be more proactive in subtly steering team choices without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly, trusting early success and keeping compositions stable; her leadership on Mission 2 reinforced the idea that the initial read on Eve was correct and she didn’t seem to second-guess that trust. She appeared more focused on maintaining successful patterns than on deeply hunting for Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Followed the emerging consensus and leaned heavily on previously successful players, especially Eve. His Mission 3 team choice (Alice and Eve only) showed strong reliance on prior success and trust rather than paranoia about hidden information.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed effectively in the background, never appearing on a mission, which kept her completely off the radar as evil. Her low profile helped maintain the illusion that all mission results were clean because the visible players were all good.
player_observations.Eve: Her central presence on every mission, combined with consistently clean results, signaled both competence and hidden information consistent with Merlin. She projected calm confidence in the team selections, which encouraged others to keep including her and ultimately made her a clear Merlin target at the end.

reflections.self_assessment: I pushed an early small team on Mission 3 that I felt good about and tried to keep table talk focused on concrete mission results. However, I clearly misread Diana and didn’t press hard enough on the implications of Mission 2’s fail, which let evil stay comfortably hidden and led me to propose a losing team.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, giving just enough gentle nudges without over-claiming knowledge, which helped her avoid getting assassinated despite consistently being on key teams.
player_observations.Bob: Had a straightforward, earnest table presence and stuck to logical reasoning from mission results, but didn’t exert a lot of agenda-setting pressure, which made it easier for evil to sideline his reads.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very credible, low-friction evil game—accepted reasonable teams, avoided loud contradictions, and used the trust from Mission 1 to slip onto later critical missions and sabotage them.
player_observations.Eve: Positioned herself as a ‘reasonable skeptic’ after the Mission 2 fail, directing suspicion outward without being too defensive, and used leadership opportunities to construct teams that subtly protected fellow evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my first fail on Mission 2 well, creating just enough suspicion spread between Alice and Bob without overexposing myself, and later leaned into a reasonably trustworthy table image to get back onto the final mission. I could have done more active misdirection in discussion to push suspicion harder onto Alice or Diana earlier, instead of relying so much on passivity and voting patterns to keep myself under the radar.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played very cautiously and was willing to go on multiple teams without pushing hard theories, which made her look like a flexible but somewhat non-directive good player and kept her from being a prime suspect. Her consistent mission successes when leading or included helped her appear reliably good but also meant she didn’t drive the table’s logic as much as she could have.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played like a classic Merlin: often ended up on the right teams and subtly nudged the table away from bad comps without making loud accusations, which made his eventual role readable in hindsight. His presence on the final failing team shows he got a bit too comfortable with me as good, which gave me the opening to stay on that mission.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s missions and team choices were mostly clean and logical, which gave her a solid good aura, but she didn’t leverage that trust aggressively enough to lock out evil from the later teams. Her final team choice including me suggests she prioritized balancing suspicions over fully committing to a strong good-only read list.
player_observations.Eve: Eve played a lower-profile evil game, allowing me to take the more visible risk on the early fail while she blended in behind safe mission results. Her appearance on the failing Mission 4 without drawing overwhelming heat showed she managed table talk well enough that suspicion stayed nicely diffused among multiple players.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed convincingly under the radar as evil, especially by leading a clean first mission that built trust in me and my early reads. However, I didn’t do enough to steer team selections later or seed effective suspicion on Merlin candidates, which left Eve with too little clear direction for the assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforward and consistently trustworthy, accepting teams and decisions that made her look clean without overexplaining her logic.
player_observations.Bob: Very subtle Merlin game; he influenced team choices just enough to keep them clean while avoiding loud, standout moves that would draw the assassin’s attention.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as a stable, reliable presence whose leadership choices felt safe and reasonable, which made her a plausible Merlin candidate from the evil perspective.
player_observations.Eve: Tried to piece together Merlin from limited information, but ultimately leaned too hard on apparent leadership and perceived centrality in the discussions when making the assassination guess.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively uncontroversial as Assassin and helped create a game state where evil wasn’t obviously exposed, but I failed to correctly track subtle Merlin signals and mis-assassinated Eve instead of Bob. I need to pay more attention to voting patterns and team proposals that quietly point to consistently correct reads, and be more suspicious of players who are ‘helpful’ without drawing overt attention.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very quiet, cooperative evil role, letting clean missions go through without resistance to keep suspicion low, which effectively protected both of us from scrutiny. Her willingness to pass on obvious fail opportunities suggests a preference for long-con, low-information evil play.
player_observations.Bob: Showed strong, consistent influence over team selection and quietly ended up on every successful mission without triggering much suspicion, a very Merlin-like pattern. He managed to guide teams correctly while not being overtly defensive or loud, which made him harder to peg as Merlin in real time.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and trustworthy, accepting and participating in clean teams in a way that felt naturally good rather than orchestrated. Her apparent lack of over-analysis or agenda made her seem like a standard good player rather than a power role, which helped divert attention away from her.
player_observations.Eve: Played a relatively low-impact good game, not strongly steering team proposals or outcomes, which made her an appealing but ultimately incorrect assassination target. Her quieter presence and lack of obvious role-signaling made it easy to over-interpret small behaviors as possible Merlin hints.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 and 4 fails in a way that kept suspicion somewhat distributed, especially by not overpushing for early sabotages and blending in with team logic. However, I could have done more to subtly steer the assassin away from Eve and toward Alice by questioning Alice’s accurate reads more aggressively and creating stronger, earlier narratives that painted her as cautious-good rather than secretly well-informed.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled and measured Merlin game, feeding information gradually and avoiding obvious hard-pushes that would mark her as a power role. Her team selections were quietly accurate, which in hindsight should have been a bigger red flag than Eve’s more visible leadership.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, Bob committed to the Eve narrative, suggesting he was reading surface-level behavior and visible influence more than subtle information-control. He stayed reasonably low-key during missions but could be nudged in his suspicions, which made him somewhat steerable but also capable of locking into a wrong-but-confident guess.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and consistent, which made her look solidly good and not particularly controversial in team discussions. Her presence on both the early success and the failed Mission 3 created some ambiguity, but she didn’t overdefend herself, which actually helped her credibility.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s visible leadership and involvement in key missions made her an attractive candidate for the assassin, especially since she looked proactive and influential. She projected a confident, central-good vibe that unintentionally drew the night-kill attention away from the more subtly correct Merlin signals from Alice.

reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and stayed consistent in my voting, which helped me look reasonably trustworthy for most of the game. However, I didn’t push hard enough on the logic after Mission 3’s fail and especially after Mission 4, and I should have been more vocal in questioning Alice and Eve instead of letting the narrative be driven by others.

player_observations.Alice: Very effective at blending in, especially by taking a small, controlled team on Mission 3 that only had one fail, which made that mission ambiguous instead of clearly condemning her.
player_observations.Bob: Played a subtle Merlin game, trying not to be too obvious, but may have been slightly too quiet or indirect at key moments, which made it easier for evil to survive without drawing the assassin’s fire earlier.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally trustworthy with her early successful leadership, but may have been a bit too open to repeating team patterns, which let evil hide inside familiar lineups.
player_observations.Eve: Navigated suspicion well by being on early successful missions and then positioning herself in mixed teams later, using just enough uncertainty to keep people from hard-clearing or hard-accusing her.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified both evil players fairly early, but I struggled to signal that information clearly enough without exposing myself as Merlin. I need to improve at subtly steering team selections and mission votes so that good players have more confidence in the right reads, while still leaving enough ambiguity to avoid an easy assassin shot.

player_observations.Alice: Very willing to go on missions and took leadership proactively, which made her look slightly suspicious after Mission 2 but ultimately consistent and transparent in discussion.
player_observations.Bob: Played a convincing, measured game as assassin, mixing cooperation and a single fail early to build trust and then coordinating the decisive double-fail on Mission 5.
player_observations.Diana: Approached the game cautiously and seemed to rely heavily on mission results over social reads, which made her slower to pivot away from early assumptions.
player_observations.Eve: Played aggressively and kept herself central to team compositions, managing to appear just plausible enough as good despite being on two failing missions, which created confusion and doubt among the good players.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy by accepting and proposing safe teams, which helped build a clear circle of trust and contributed to three clean mission successes. I could improve by being more vocal in pushing narratives that misdirect the assassin, especially around who looked most like Merlin once it was clear our teams were working perfectly.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cleanly and reliably, which made her an attractive but ultimately incorrect Merlin candidate for the assassin. She was willing to go on early missions and didn’t over-coordinate, which helped maintain a low profile.
player_observations.Bob: Managed to get first leadership and still let a fully good team through, suggesting a conservative or cautious evil style. He avoided overt sabotage, likely hoping to create confusion later through social reads instead of early mission fails.
player_observations.Diana: Balanced giving subtly correct approvals with not over-controlling the table, which is strong Merlin discipline. Her low-key guidance toward safe teams while avoiding obvious spotlight was key to our perfect mission record and the assassin’s wrong guess.
player_observations.Eve: Focused on the most visible, reliable-seeming good player (Alice) as Merlin, which shows a tendency to equate mechanical cleanliness with information advantage. She didn’t seem to pressure-test quieter players like Diana enough, which ultimately cost the assassination.
player_observations.Assassin: Approached the guess by targeting the most mechanically confirmed and central-seeming good player rather than the most subtly guiding voice. The decision suggests a preference for straightforward, surface-level Merlin reads over tracking nuanced voting and leadership influence.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fails well and stayed consistent in my table talk, which helped keep suspicion spread rather than focused on me. I could improve by planting stronger, earlier narratives about specific players being evil, so that the eventual Merlin hunt feels more grounded and less like a guess.

player_observations.Alice: Alice tended to accept being placed on early teams and played fairly cooperatively, which made her look generically good but also a bit passive in shaping the narrative.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played subtly and avoided drawing attention, benefiting from mission outcomes without loudly steering discussion, which helped him stay under the radar as evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie tried to reason from mission data and was vocal about logic, but sometimes pivoted too quickly, which made it easier to muddy his reads and cast doubt on his conclusions.
player_observations.Eve: Eve was cautious and avoided making too-sharp accusations, which protected her Merlin identity but also meant her influence on team selection was more indirect than it could have been.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-profile and let the clean missions build trust, which helped evil win without drawing suspicion directly onto me. I could improve by being a bit more actively involved in discussion to subtly steer decisions, rather than risking being read as quiet but harmless.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward and trusting way, approving and joining early successful teams, which made her look reliably good and a natural core for teams.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed to follow the emerging consensus, leaning on table reads more than pushing his own, which kept him under the radar but also made him a bit easier to influence.
player_observations.Charlie: Assassin instincts were sharp, correctly identifying Merlin despite all missions succeeding, suggesting careful attention to who had extra information or overly accurate reads.
player_observations.Eve: Balanced giving just enough correct guidance to secure all-success missions while not pushing too hard against evil, but ultimately her subtle hints were still enough to get her correctly pegged as Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently believable as good by anchoring Mission 1 with a clean success and then only failing missions when it made strategic sense, which helped evil win without drawing too much suspicion directly onto me. I could improve by creating more proactive, vocal suspicion on non-Merlin good players earlier so that the endgame assassination would feel less pressured and more clearly directed.

player_observations.Alice: Very composed and willing to go on multiple teams, which made her look reliably good—but her presence on almost every key team was a subtle Merlin tell. She managed information carefully rather than loudly, suggesting she prefers quiet influence over overt table control.
player_observations.Bob: Played fairly straightforwardly good, going on multiple teams and not overasserting accusations, which made him a solid 'default trust' candidate. He seemed to follow the social consensus more than drive it, which can make him harder to read but also less dangerous as Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: His leadership on Mission 3 and willingness to take a small team with me suggested he was trying to be logical and risk-aware, which read very village-leaning. He didn’t strongly push any radical theories, so his playstyle comes off as methodical but not highly deceptive.
player_observations.Eve: Handled the evil role well by taking a pivotal leadership position twice and spreading the fails across different missions to avoid a clear pattern. Her team selections and participation created just enough ambiguity around where the evil players were, which gave me room to stay relatively under the radar as assassin.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Alice early and helped secure clean teams on Missions 1 and 3, but I struggled to convert that information into a consistent good-team bloc later in the game. I should have been more suspicious of Eve after Mission 4’s fail and more vocal about pushing Bob/Charlie apart on the final mission instead of accepting a risky mixed team.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to appear consistently trustworthy, staying on multiple successful teams, which made her a stabilizing anchor for the good team even though we didn’t fully leverage that reliability in the endgame.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he played cautiously and avoided drawing too much suspicion, but his influence on late-game team selection seemed muted, suggesting either quiet signaling that wasn’t picked up or overcautiousness when he needed to be more forceful.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled evil game, embedding himself in mixed teams without attracting overwhelming blame, and managed to stay viable enough to be included on the final mission despite the fail on Mission 2.
player_observations.Eve: Blended into the mid-game well, only revealing through the Mission 4 fail, which indicates a patient, low-profile evil style that capitalized on the confusion between Bob and Charlie.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently village-leaning and built trust early by being on and leading only successful missions, which helped make me a natural inclusion on teams. I could improve by being a bit more suspicious and vocal about potential evil players like Charlie, and by subtly protecting Bob more so he was a less obvious Merlin target.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean, trustworthy game, repeatedly ending up on successful teams and projecting a straightforward good alignment without drawing much suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Gave strong but not overbearing directional input, subtly nudging team compositions toward all-good lineups in a way that in hindsight clearly reflected Merlin-level information.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to avoid being tested on critical missions, which let them blend in somewhat, but ultimately couldn’t disrupt the momentum of the early all-good mission successes.
player_observations.Eve: Took a big swing in the Assassin phase by targeting me, suggesting they read my confident good play as possible Merlin, but they seemed to have limited information due to how quickly the good team locked in clean missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good by supporting and leading clean teams, especially on Missions 1 and 3, which helped build trust in me as a safe pick. I could improve by being more vocal in questioning others’ logic to better identify the assassin and protect Merlin more deliberately in the endgame.

player_observations.Alice: Played subtly enough to get onto Mission 2 without drawing strong suspicion, suggesting a preference for blending in rather than hard-pushing narratives.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a classic cautious Merlin, nudging teams toward safe compositions without over-explaining and keeping his information disguised behind ‘reasonable’ logic.
player_observations.Charlie: Assumed the assassin role aggressively by trying to read social dynamics and leaning into the final guess, but miscalibrated on Merlin and seemed to overvalue surface-level trust patterns.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as straightforward and genuinely good, but didn’t assert themselves strongly in the Merlin hunt, which likely contributed to the assassin’s incorrect read.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on missions and helped secure three clean successes, which made it easier for Merlin and the rest of the team to read me as good. I could have pushed harder on the logic after Mission 3 and 4 fails to narrow down the evil team earlier and to better shield Alice from suspicion going into the final mission and assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very calm and controlled Merlin game, guiding team choices toward clean missions without drawing too much heat; her inclusion patterns were subtly pro-good without being obvious. Even after the Mission 4 fail, she didn’t overdefend herself, which probably helped the assassin misfire on Eve.
player_observations.Bob: Took advantage of his early trust from Mission 1 to later sneak in the fail on Mission 3, suggesting he’s comfortable playing a longer con rather than being aggressively suspicious. His assassination on Eve shows he was fairly convinced by surface-level mission history and maybe underestimated how low-key Alice’s Merlin game was.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and only directly contributed to a single failing mission on Team 4, which suggests a more passive evil style relying on others’ social reads and confusion. He didn’t strongly push misdirecting narratives, which made him less obviously evil but also less influential overall.
player_observations.Eve: As a frequent team member and final mission leader, she projected a generally trustworthy, cooperative vibe and made solid team choices in Missions 1 and 5. The assassin’s final guess on her as Merlin shows she appeared informed and confident enough in her reads that evil mistook her good play for a power role.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of early mission successes and didn’t press hard enough on reasoning and voting patterns, which let evil hide comfortably until late. I did well staying consistently on teams that looked good statistically, but I need to be more aggressive in challenging assumptions, especially after the first fail and in re-evaluating ‘cleared’ players.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled game as assassin: stayed quiet early, then leveraged the success on Mission 2 and the small Mission 3 team to gain trust while still having room to later push suspicion subtly. Her fail on Mission 3 was well-timed, creating ambiguity between her and me without overexposing herself.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he steered teams toward mostly safe configurations early (especially Mission 1 and avoiding suspicious mixes) but was cautious enough not to hard-clear or hard-accuse, which kept him alive until the end. His influence on the final team composition was strong but not transparent, which is solid Merlin play even though good ultimately lost.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very straightforward, good-leaning style and seemed to base decisions mostly on mission results rather than deeper vote-analysis or role inference. This made him look reliably good but also fairly easy to sway, especially going into the final mission where he accepted a team that still had hidden evil.
player_observations.Eve: Blended in extremely well as evil by taking leadership on Missions 2 and 5 and proposing teams that looked reasonable given past successes, especially Mission 2’s clean result to earn long-term trust. Her choice of the final team (Alice, Bob, Charlie) was subtle enough that it didn’t immediately scream ‘stacked evil,’ which helped secure the last fail.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent in trusting Alice, which was correct, but I didn’t push hard enough to clear Charlie as likely Merlin and protect him more clearly going into the endgame. On my own mission as leader, I picked a risky team including Eve without demanding stronger justification, which gave evil a crucial fail and signaled that my reads weren’t solid. I need to be more vocal about my suspicions earlier and anchor my decisions more on mission results and voting patterns instead of social impressions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very steady, low-flash good game; she was often on correct teams but didn’t over-assert herself, which made her look reliably but not obviously good. Her willingness to go on multiple early teams without loud resistance made her a natural hub for both good and evil players to cluster around.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well by accepting some good-looking team compositions while slipping in subtle sabotage at key points, especially on Missions 2 and 5. His playstyle leaned on being flexible with his approvals/denials so his voting record didn’t clearly out him as evil until it was too late.
player_observations.Charlie: Gave just enough quiet directional nudges to good-leaning teams without hard-clearing anyone, which is strong Merlin play but also made it harder for us to rally around him as clearly good. His understated influence helped guide some good decisions, but the subtlety also kept us from fully capitalizing on his information.
player_observations.Eve: Leveraged an early clean mission (Mission 1) to establish a strong trust base and repeatedly positioned herself on teams that looked reasonable from the outside. She played assertively as leader, especially on Missions 1 and 5, using confident team proposals to make her inclusion feel natural rather than suspicious.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed very low-key as Merlin: I nudged missions toward Alice and Charlie without making it obvious I had extra information, which helped the assassin misfire onto Alice. I could improve by adding a bit more visible doubt or occasional mild disagreement, so my behavior looks more like a cautious generic good player rather than someone subtly steering perfectly correct teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean good game, projecting trustworthiness without overexplaining, which made her a natural lightning rod for the assassin’s suspicion. She was decisive in accepting good teams, which helped missions go smoothly but also made her look like a potential information role.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well as evil by not being too aggressive and allowing the early missions to pass, aiming for a longer game or an assassin win rather than early mission fails. However, the consistent success of teams without him gradually made his alignment more suspect to anyone tracking team compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and collaborative, which made it easy for me as Merlin to back them without raising alarms. Their willingness to go on early missions and not over-defend themselves reinforced a genuine good-player image.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, relied heavily on social reads and visible leadership patterns, ultimately keying in on Alice’s confident correctness as a Merlin tell. The final guess showed a solid logic path (targeting the consistently right and trusted player), even though it missed the subtler, quieter Merlin play I was aiming for.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected Bob or Diana were likely evil after the early fails, but I didn’t communicate that strongly or clearly enough through my voting and discussions, which let evil steer the late missions. I also allowed too much ambiguity around Charlie, which made it easier for Diana to survive and eventually secure the win. Next time I should more deliberately shape team compositions and voting patterns to signal my information without overexposing myself as Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played consistently pro-mission and ended up on multiple teams, which made her look slightly suspicious after repeated fails but her calm, steady demeanor kept her from being a prime suspect.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well by leading a successful first mission and then staying out of the spotlight, which helped deflect suspicion away from him after later fails.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed a generally logical, good-leaning thought process but struggled to lock onto the right evil pair, making him vulnerable to being subtly steered by assassin-aligned arguments.
player_observations.Diana: Balanced aggression and subtlety effectively, joining key failing missions while not appearing overly pushy, and leveraged the confusion around team compositions to guide the table toward misreads that ultimately won the game for evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I kept missions clean and successfully steered all three teams to success, but I was far too obviously central to those successes and didn't diffuse suspicion onto others. Next time I should hide my information better by occasionally pushing harder for alternative teams, allowing more table talk, and making my reads appear more tentative and social rather than accurate and directive.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, cooperative way and accepted being on early teams without much visible paranoia, which made her seem naturally good-aligned and easy to trust for team building.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed willing to go along with established trust rather than forcing his own views, which helped him blend in as a flexible, low-conflict good player but also made his alignment harder to read from behavior alone.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed off the critical mission teams yet still maintained enough presence that his lack of involvement didn’t raise major alarms, a quiet assassin posture that preserved him for an accurate endgame guess.
player_observations.Diana: Managed to avoid being the focal point of suspicion despite being evil, largely by not contesting the successful teams too aggressively and letting others (including me) drive the mission direction.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my sabotage on Missions 2 and 4 well, keeping suspicion diffuse and helping secure the evil win without drawing too much heat onto myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Diana and the mission compositions earlier, to better control where Merlin’s suspicions landed and to create more misdirection about who the true threats were.

player_observations.Alice: She played a cautious but influential Merlin, often placing herself on early teams and using subtle steering rather than aggressive accusations, which made her reads harder to detect as ‘Merlin-like’ in the moment.
player_observations.Bob: He tended to follow the emerging table consensus and was relatively quiet in pushing his own theories, making him appear generally trustworthy but also easier to mislead with confident claims from others.
player_observations.Charlie: He played straightforwardly and placed a lot of weight on mission results over social reads, which made him predictable in his team preferences and somewhat easier to manipulate by shaping which missions succeeded or failed.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she blended in well with the good team’s reasoning and didn’t over-defend suspicious players, which helped preserve her cover; at times she could have been even more assertive in seeding alternative suspects to pull attention away from the actual Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed convincingly under the radar as evil, timing my fail on Mission 4 well so it didn’t point too hard at me and kept suspicion spread out. I could improve by being more proactive in shaping the narrative earlier, especially around Mission 2’s fail, to more strongly frame alternative suspects and better protect my partners.

player_observations.Alice: Alice tended to trust early mission success as strong evidence of goodness and was willing to re-include previous teammates, which made her a stabilizing but somewhat predictable force. She didn’t push very hard on deeper deduction after the first fail, which let misleading narratives persist.
player_observations.Bob: Bob (as Merlin) played cautiously and tried to avoid drawing direct attention, often preferring subtle steering of team compositions over loud accusations. His reluctance to hard-clear or hard-condemn players made it harder for good to coalesce around a correct read, which benefited evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie (as assassin) took a more aggressive risk by failing Mission 2 on a three-person team, which created confusion but also some heat on that group. His willingness to accept suspicion in the midgame helped keep attention off me and complicated good’s attempts to lock in a trusted core.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played in a very mission-outcome-focused way, heavily weighting success/fail results when forming her reads. She seemed genuinely flexible but somewhat reactive, which made her easier to subtly influence when proposing or evaluating later teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively hidden as the Assassin and didn’t draw much suspicion, which kept evil theoretically dangerous going into the endgame. However, I failed to identify Merlin correctly and underestimated Bob’s subtle influence while overvaluing Diana’s apparent centrality in team selection. In future games, I should track vote patterns and who quietly benefits from correct teams more carefully.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared trustworthy and accepted on teams, suggesting a calm, straightforward good playstyle that didn’t over-assert itself. Her willingness to go on early missions without drama made it harder to pin any strong signal on her alignment.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-key Merlin, guiding successful teams without being obviously vocal or pushy, which effectively concealed his role. His influence seemed to come more from not opposing good teams than from aggressively steering discussions.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to avoid enough suspicion that their evil alignment didn’t derail the missions, likely by not over-contesting successful team proposals. Their subtlety kept the focus off them, but it also didn’t create enough chaos to help evil turn the game.
player_observations.Diana: Appeared central and trustworthy, especially by leading Mission 2 to a success and repeatedly being included on teams, which made her look like a strong Merlin candidate. Her confident participation and presence on every mission made her an attractive but ultimately incorrect assassination target.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently aligned with other good players and avoided drawing assassin attention, which helped protect Merlin indirectly. However, I could have contributed more actively to discussion by pressing suspicious players (especially Alice) instead of mostly following the emerging consensus.

player_observations.Alice: Played subtly and avoided obvious sabotage early, which helped her blend in despite being evil; her willingness to go on all-success teams without resistance was a bit too compliant and could be a future tell.
player_observations.Bob: Very controlled and measured in his support of teams, giving just enough guidance to steer towards safe groups without over-directing discussion and revealing himself as Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, he seemed slightly out of sync with team formation logic and ended up misreading who was driving the good decisions, which led to the wrong Merlin guess.
player_observations.Diana: Showed solid, straightforward good-play logic, especially in mission selection and voting, and projected a reliable presence that made it easy for others to trust her on teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently village-leaning in tone and team choices, especially by backing Alice and Diana on key missions and proposing the winning team on Mission 5. I could improve by pushing harder on structured reasoning after Mission 3 and 4 fails, since I mostly relied on vibe reads rather than clearly narrowing down the evil pair, which might have helped misdirect the assassin even more.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-key Merlin game—gave just enough support to good teams (especially Missions 2 and 5) without being loud or over-directive, which helped avoid the assassin’s final guess.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well early with a strong social presence and took advantage of the clean Mission 1 to build trust, but the fail on Mission 3 followed by his overall positioning made his alignment increasingly suspicious in retrospect.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and let others drive the team discussions, which helped mask evil alignment for a while, but the failed Mission 4 with Alice and me on it created a lot of late-game doubt around that team slot.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally trustworthy and consistent; being on both an early success (Mission 1) and the final success (Mission 5) reinforced a solid good image, and she didn’t overcomplicate the table with unnecessary speculation.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed under the radar well by joining two successful missions first, then contributing to well-timed fails on Missions 4 and 5 without drawing too much suspicion. I could improve by more actively steering suspicion toward a specific good player to create a clearer narrative, rather than relying mostly on quiet consistency and the chaos from late fails.

player_observations.Alice: As assassin, Alice took a more low-key approach, only directly sabotaging once and otherwise letting the table dynamics evolve, which helped keep evil’s footprint small. Her willingness to fail the small Mission 3 with Diana was a strong pivot point that shifted the game’s trust structure.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played a very convincing Merlin by blending in as a generally logical good player rather than overtly steering teams, which reduced kill pressure on him. His inclusion on the final failing team suggests he was trusted broadly, indicating he managed his information reveals subtly.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s playstyle seemed straightforward and principled, which made him look reliably good but not necessarily central to team-building decisions. His presence on the final mission without raising alarm suggests he didn’t aggressively push theories, making him a relatively “safe” include for others.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s repeated leadership and early mission success built a lot of table trust, which she used to form later mission teams that unfortunately included hidden evil. Her willingness to re-team with previous members (including me) showed a preference for consistency once she felt someone was cleared.

reflections.self_assessment: I balanced early trust-building with well-timed sabotages, especially by leading safe-looking teams on Missions 1 and 3 before pushing the decisive fails on Missions 4 and 5. I could improve by creating more ambiguity around who the second evil player was, as the double-fail on Mission 5 may have narrowed suspicion onto a smaller subset of players.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played in a straightforward, consistently pro-mission way that made her look reliably good, which helped me hide behind her credibility on several teams.
player_observations.Bob: Bob was patient with his assassin role, choosing spots to fail that didn’t overexpose him early and coordinating the final double-fail effectively.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played a cautious Merlin, steering teams away from stacked evil but doing so subtly enough that their soft pushes didn’t immediately give away their identity.
player_observations.Diana: Diana tended to follow table consensus and logic more than driving it, which made her look sincere but also slightly easier to sway regarding team approvals.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably inconspicuous as evil, letting missions pass without drawing suspicion, but I failed to read Merlin correctly and mis-assassinated Alice instead of Diana. I need to pay closer attention to subtle information steering, especially from players who appear quiet or cooperative but consistently land on successful mission teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean, low-drama good game; being repeatedly trusted on teams without controversy made her look like a plausible Merlin decoy.
player_observations.Bob: As my fellow evil, Bob blended in well enough that team compositions didn’t trigger strong doubts, but didn’t generate much misdirection around Merlin identity.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and logic-driven, which helped him get on teams; his playstyle felt more like a confident good than a hidden information role.
player_observations.Diana: Kept a relatively low profile while quietly ending up on critical teams, offering just enough guidance to shape team choices without sounding like she had extra information—classic subtle Merlin behavior that I underestimated.
